White House secretaries prepared verbatim transcripts, and in accordance with Judge Sirica's order, copies went to St. Clair—who had not previously listened to any of the tapes, as Nixon had never granted him access.{{Cite magazine| title=The Unmaking of the President| url=https://www.cnn.com/ALLPOLITICS/1996/analysis/back.time/9608/21/index.shtml| date=August 19, 1974| magazine=Time| location=New York, New York| volume=104| issue=8| accessdate=November 17, 2019| via=CNN AllPolitics-Back in Time}} When transcripts were made public on August 5, a conversation on one, recorded June 23, 1972, only a few days after the break-in at the Democratic National Committee offices, proved that Nixon's assertion of having had no involvement in the cover-up was a lie.{{harvnb|Ambrose 1991}}, pp. 414–416.{{Cite web| title=The Last Hours of the Nixon Presidency| last=Klein| first=Christopher| date=August 30, 2018| url=https://www.history.com/news/the-last-hours-of-the-nixon-presidency-40-years-ago| website=history.com| orig-year=Original date: August 8, 2014| publisher=A&E Television Networks| accessdate=October 7, 2019}} The tape, later known as the [[Nixon White House tapes#The "smoking gun" tape|"smoking gun" tape]], documented the initial stages of the Watergate cover-up. On it, Nixon and then-Chief of Staff H. R. Haldeman are heard formulating a plan to block investigations by having the CIA falsely claim to the FBI that national security was involved. This demonstrated both that Nixon had been told of the White House connection to the Watergate burglaries soon after they took place, and that he had approved plans to thwart the investigation. In a statement accompanying the release of the tape, Nixon accepted blame for misleading the country about when he had been told of White House involvement, saying he had a lapse of memory.{{cite news| author=| agency=[[Associated Press|AP]]| title=Refusal-to-Resign Speech Was Prepared for Nixon| url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/special/nixon/stories/nixon121696ap.htm| date=December 16, 1996| newspaper=The Washington Post| accessdate=November 11, 2019}} === Political fallout === The following morning, August 6, Nixon attempted to rally his Cabinet's continued support. "In my opinion and in the opinion of my counsel, I have not committed any impeachable offense," he asserted. Therefore, he declared, "the constitutional process should be followed out to the end—wherever the end may be."{{Cite magazine| title=The Unmaking of the President| url=https://www.cnn.com/ALLPOLITICS/1996/analysis/back.time/9608/21/index.shtml| date=August 19, 1974| magazine=Time| location=New York, New York| volume=104| issue=8| accessdate=November 17, 2019| via=CNN AllPolitics-Back in Time}} In response, Vice President Ford, who had been crisscrossing the nation for months speaking in defense of the president,{{cite news| title=Ford Shuttles Between the Capitol and White House| last=Hunter| first=Marjorie| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1974/08/07/archives/ford-shuttles-between-the-capitol-and-white-house-avoids-comment.html| date=August 7, 1974| page=16| newspaper=The New York Times| accessdate=December 11, 2019}} told Nixon that while he would continue to support Nixon's policies, he would no longer speak to the media or to the public on the subject of impeachment;{{harvnb|Ford|1979}}, pp. 20–21. Ford had issued a statement the previous evening saying he would "respectfully decline to discuss impeachment matters in public or in response to questions until the facts are more fully available." Confronted with the incontrovertible fact that Nixon had played a leading role in the Watergate cover-up from its initial stages, the ranks of Nixon's defenders in Congress thinned rapidly. Various Senate Republicans expressed their "shock or outrage" and echoed the growing sentiment favoring the president's resignation.{{cite news| title=Resignation Urged By GOP Senators| last=Rich| first=Spencer| date=August 7, 1974| page=1| url=http://jfk.hood.edu/Collection/White%20Materials/Watergate/Watergate%20Items%2017131%20to%2017456/Watergate%2017417.pdf| newspaper=The Washington Post| accessdate=November 17, 2019| via=The Weisberg Collection, Hood College, Frederick, Maryland}} In a pointed statement, [[Robert P. Griffin]], the [[Whip (politics)|assistant minority leader]], urged the president to resign, saying: "I think we've arrived at a point where both the national interest and his own (Nixon's) interest would best be served by resigning."{{cite news| title=Griffin tells Nixon it's Time to Resign| last=Rich| first=Spencer| date=August 6, 1974| page=1| newspaper=The Washington Post| url=http://jfk.hood.edu/Collection/White%20Materials/Watergate/Watergate%20Items%2017131%20to%2017456/Watergate%2017349.pdf| accessdate=January 25, 2020| via=The Weisberg Collection, Hood College, Frederick, Maryland}} [[Bob Dole]] speculated that "if the president had 40 votes (for acquittal in a Senate trial) a week ago, he had no more than 20 today." Nixon would have needed 34 votes to avoid conviction and removal from office.{{cite news| title=Decline In Senate| last=Apple Jr.| first=R. W.| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1974/08/07/archives/decline-in-senate-dole-says-president-now-has-no-more-than-20-votes.html| date=August 7, 1974| page=1| newspaper=The New York Times| accessdate=December 11, 2019}} Additionally, [[John Tower]] said a tentative decision had been made "to send a delegation to the president to advise him of the strong sentiment among Republicans for retirement and to warn him that he will very likely be convicted in the Senate if he does not resign first." [[Barry Goldwater]] agreed later that day to lead the delegation. [[File:Informal press conference following a meeting between Congressmen and the President to discuss Watergate matters. - NARA - 194590.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.05|Senators Scott and Goldwater and Representative Rhodes hold an informal press conference following their August{{nbsp}}7 meeting with the president]] There was a continuous barrage of similar public declarations throughout the day by various House Republicans. Minority Leader Rhodes, declared: "Cover-up of criminal activity and misuse of federal agencies can neither be condoned nor tolerated." He vowed that: "When the roll is called in the House of Representatives, I will vote 'aye' on impeachment."{{cite news| last=Barnes| first=Bart| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/john-j-rhodes-dies-led-gop-in-house-during-watergate/2012/06/05/gJQA84nSGV_story.html| title=John J. Rhodes Dies; Led GOP In House During Watergate| date=August 26, 2003| newspaper=The Washington Post| accessdate=November 19, 2019}} Additionally, all 10 of the Judiciary Committee Republicans who had voted against every article of impeachment gave indication that they would vote to impeach Nixon for obstruction of justice when the vote was taken in the full House. Edward Hutchinson, announced he would support impeachment "with a heavy heart." Charles Wiggins said, "the facts then known to me have now changed." It was now clear to him that the president had a "plan of action" to cover up the break-in. "These facts standing alone," he continued, "are legally sufficient in my opinion to sustain at least one count against the president of conspiracy to obstruct justice." "Devastating—impeachable," Charles Sandman told reporters (now having the "specificity" he had demanded during the hearings). Among the few Republicans on Capitol Hill who still defended the president following the "smoking gun" revelation was Senator [[Carl Curtis]], who implored Congress not to panic. He warned that the United States would become like a "banana republic" if Nixon was ousted in favor of Vice President Ford, who in turn would then select someone to fill the vice presidential slot. He said "this would mean both Ford and the new Vice President would be men who hadn't been elected to their high office, but merely nominated by a president under procedures for filling the vice presidency when it is vacant." Congressman [[Earl Landgrebe]] did as well, declaring: "Don't confuse me with the facts. I've got a closed mind. I will not vote for impeachment. I'm going to stick with my president even if he and I have to be taken out of this building and shot."{{cite news| last=Pearson| first=Richard| title=Obituaries| date=July 1, 1986| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/local/1986/07/01/obituaries/1a979939-0198-4aaf-9945-71e239df1e36/| newspaper=The Washington Post| accessdate=November 18, 2019}} During the late afternoon of August 7, senators Goldwater and Scott and Congressman Rhodes met with Nixon in the Oval Office and told him his support in Congress had all but disappeared.{{harvnb|Woodward|Bernstein|2005}}, pp. 413–417. They did not pressure Nixon to resign, Scott told reporters afterward, but simply that "the situation is very gloomy on Capitol Hill."{{cite news| title='Gloomy' Picture| last=Berbers| first=John| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1974/08/08/archives/gloomy-picture-kissinger-remains-at-white-house-office-beyond.html| page=1| newspaper=The New York Times| date=August 8, 1974| accessdate=December 11, 2019}} Rhodes told the president he would face certain impeachment when the articles came up for vote in the full House. Goldwater and Scott told the president there were not only enough votes in the Senate to convict him, no more than 15 or so senators were willing to vote for acquittal. Goldwater later wrote that as a result of the meeting, Nixon "knew beyond any doubt that one way or another his presidency was finished."{{cite news| title=In 1974, Goldwater and Rhodes told Nixon he was doomed| last=Nowicki| first=Don| date=August 2, 2014| url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/azdc/2014/08/03/goldwater-rhodes-nixon-resignation/13497493/| newspaper=The Arizona Republic| accessdate=November 19, 2019}} That night, Nixon finalized his decision to leave office. == Resignation and conclusion == [[File:Nixon Resign.ogg|thumb|Nixon announces that he will resign]] [[File:NIXONSandFORDS.jpg|thumb|upright=1|President Nixon and the first lady (in pink) leave the White House, accompanied by Vice President Ford and the second lady, August 9, 1974, shortly before Nixon's resignation [[Coming into force|became effective]]]] Nixon met with Vice President Ford the following morning, August 8, to inform Ford of his intention to resign from office, and met with congressional leaders that evening to give them formal notice. Next, he met briefly with a group of longtime congressional friends, and then [[Richard Nixon's resignation speech|he informed the nation]]. Several days earlier, in advance of the release of the tapes on August 5, presidential speechwriter [[Ray Price (speechwriter)|Ray Price]] had prepared two draft speeches for the president—one, a refusal-to-resign speech, and the second, a resignation speech.{{harvnb|Small|1999}}, p. 295. The latter served as the first draft of the speech Nixon delivered live on radio and television from the Oval Office that night. In his address, Nixon said he was resigning because "I have concluded that because of the Watergate matter I might not have the support of the Congress that I would consider necessary to back the very difficult decisions and carry out the duties of this office in the way the interests of the nation would require." He also stated his hope that, by resigning, "I will have hastened the start of that process of healing which is so desperately needed in America." He then went on to review the accomplishments of his presidency, especially in foreign policy.{{harvnb|Ambrose|1991}}, pp. 435–436.{{harvnb|Kutler|1990}}, pp. 547–549. Nixon acknowledged that some of his judgments "were wrong," and he expressed contrition, saying: "I deeply regret any injuries that may have been done in the course of the events that led to this decision." The speech contained no admission of wrongdoing, however, nor did it mention the articles of impeachment pending against him.{{harvnb|Black|2007}}, p. 983. Protesters outside the White House along [[Pennsylvania Avenue]] shouted "{{hsp}}jail to the chief{{hsp}}" throughout the night. On the morning of August 9, 1974, after an emotional farewell to his Cabinet members and staff, Nixon and his family left the White House for San Clemente, California. He left behind a signed letter of resignation addressed to Secretary of State Kissinger, becoming the first U.S. president to resign from office. His presidency officially ended at 11:35 am, when Kissinger received the letter, and Ford's began.{{cite news| author=| title=News Summary and Index Saturday, August 10, 1974: The presidency| date=August 10, 1974| page=31| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1974/08/10/archives/news-summary-and-index-the-major-events-of-the-day-the-presidency.html| newspaper=The New York Times| accessdate=October 7, 2019}} A short while later, in the [[East Room]] of the White House, [[Inauguration of Gerald Ford|Ford was sworn into office]] by Chief Justice Burger, declaring "our long national nightmare is over."{{harvnb|Small|1999}}, p. 297. Following Nixon's resignation, the impeachment process against him was closed.{{Cite news| title=House Formally Concludes Inquiry Into Impeachment| last=Rosenbaum| first=David E.| newspaper=The New York Times| date=August 21, 1974| page=20| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1974/08/21/archives/house-formally-concludes-inquiry-into-impeachment-sets-out-evidence.html| accessdate=November 12, 2019}} On August 20, the House voted to accept the final Judiciary Committee report by a vote of 412 to 3, with Republican Earl Landgrebe, plus Democrats [[Otto Passman]] and [[Sonny Montgomery]] casting the only no votes.{{Cite news| last=Colwell| first=Jack| url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/40758521/the_south_bend_tribune/| title=Defends Nixon to the End |date=August 21, 1974| page=1| newspaper=The South Bend Tribune| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191218183500/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/40758521/the_south_bend_tribune/ |archive-date=December 18, 2019 |url-status=live| accessdate=December 18, 2019| via=[[Newspapers.com]]}}{{Cite magazine| last=Werth| first=Barry| title=The Pardon| date=February 2007| magazine=Smithsonian Magazine| url=https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/the-pardon-144711443/| accessdate=October 7, 2019}} The 528‐page report, published on August 22, laid out in detail what it called the "clear and convincing evidence" against Nixon. It also contained a statement from the committee's Republican members who had originally opposed impeachment, stating for the record that Nixon had not been "hounded from office" but rather had destroyed his own presidency through his patterns of deceit.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1974/08/23/archives/rodino-unit-issues-report-describing-case-against-nixon-rodino.html| title=Rodino Unit Issues Report Describing Case Against Nixon| first=David E.| last=Rosenbaum| newspaper=The New York Times| page=| date=August 23, 1974| accessdate=December 18, 2019}} == Epilogue == Though Nixon had not faced impeachment by the full House or a Senate trial, criminal prosecution was still a possibility at both the federal and state levels.{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,942980,00.html |title=The Legal Aftermath Citizen Nixon and the Law |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=August 19, 1974 |accessdate=July 24, 2011}} Concerned about Nixon's well-being, and worried that the "ugly passions" aroused by the Watergate scandal would rise again during a lengthy Nixon prosecution, on September 8, 1974, President Ford granted [[Pardon of Richard Nixon|Nixon a pardon]] for all crimes he had "committed or may have committed or taken part in" as president.{{Cite web| last=van der Voort| first=Tom| title=Watergate: The Aftermath| url=https://millercenter.org/the-presidency/educational-resources/watergate/watergate-aftermath| work=The Presidency Educational Resources| publisher=The Miller Center, University of Virginia| location=Charlottesville, Virginia| accessdate=October 17, 2019}} Nixon, in his official acceptance of the pardon, said that he "was wrong in not acting more decisively and more forthrightly in dealing with Watergate, particularly when it reached the stage of judicial proceedings and grew from a political scandal into a national tragedy."{{cite web| editor1-last=Fulton| editor1-first=Mary Lou| url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1990-07-17-ss-339-story.html| title=Nixon Library: Nixon Timeline| work=Los Angeles Times| date=July 17, 1990}} While accepting the pardon implied an admission of guilt,{{cite news| last=Vande Bunte| first=Matt| title=President Nixon didn't want to be pardoned, Watergate expert says| date=April 3, 2019| orig-year=October 20, 2014| url=https://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/2014/10/president_nixon_didnt_want_to.html| website=MLive.com| publisher=MLive Media Group| location=Grand Rapids, Michigan| accessdate=December 19, 2019}} Nixon maintained his innocence until his death in 1994. Public opinion at the time of the pardon was negative according to a September 6–9, 1974 Gallup Poll, which found that "only 38 percent of Americans said Ford should pardon Nixon, while 53 percent said he should not."{{cite web| last1=Newport| first1=Frank| last2=Carroll| first2=Joseph| date=March 9, 2007| title=Americans Generally Negative on Recent Presidential Pardons| url=https://news.gallup.com/poll/26830/americans-generally-negative-recent-presidential-pardons.aspx| publisher=[[Gallup (company)|Gallup]]| location=Washington, D.C.| accessdate=November 30, 2019}} Numerous congressional Democrats issued statements critical of the pardon, and in light of it, some even sought to reopen the impeachment process against the former president. Specifically, Judiciary Committee members [[Jerome Waldie]], George Danielson, and [[Don Edwards]] spoke of pressing the committee to pursue the outstanding subpoenas in order to bring all the evidence out into the open and to complete the formal record of Nixon's wrongdoing while in office. Chairman Rodino, however, declared that "impeachment is dead," forestalling such a move.{{cite web| title=Rodino Rejects Revival of Impeachment| last=Rosenbaum| first=David E.| date=September 10, 1974| page=1| newspaper=The New York Times| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1974/09/10/archives/rodino-rejects-revival-of-impeachment-rodino-bars-impeachment-move.html| accessdate=December 3, 2019}} The following month, Ford appeared voluntarily before the Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on Criminal Justice to explain the reasons behind the pardon.{{cite web| last=Greene| first=John Robert| title=Gerald Ford: Domestic Affairs| url=https://millercenter.org/president/ford/domestic-affairs| publisher=Miller Center of Public Affairs, University of Virginia| location=Charlottesville, Virginia| accessdate=January 2, 2020}} Two years later, lingering public resentment over the Nixon pardon was a factor in Ford's narrow loss to Democratic Party nominee [[Jimmy Carter]] in the [[1976 United States presidential election|1976 presidential election]]. Nationwide, the 1974 [[United States midterm election|midterm election]] was a landslide victory for the Democratic Party. In the House, Democrats won 49 seats previously held by Republicans and increased their majority above the [[Supermajority|two-thirds]] mark. Altogether, there were 93 [[Freshmen|freshmen representatives]] in the [[94th United States Congress|94th Congress]] when it convened on January 3, 1975, 76 of them Democrats. Those elected to office that year later came to be known collectively as "[[Watergate Babies]]."{{Cite web| title=How the 'Watergate Babies' Broke American Politics| last=Lawrence| first=John A.| date=May 26, 2018| url=https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2018/05/26/congress-broke-american-politics-218544| work=Politico Magazine| accessdate=October 12, 2019}} Several Republican Judiciary Committee members were defeated in the [[1974 United States House of Representatives elections|1974 elections]] by their Democratic opponents. Chief among them was Charles Sandman, who was soundly defeated by [[William J. Hughes]]. Also defeated were [[David W. Dennis]], losing to [[Philip Sharp (politician)|Philip Sharp]], Wiley Mayne, losing to [[Berkley Bedell]], [[Harold Vernon Froehlich]], losing to [[Robert John Cornell]], and [[Joseph J. Maraziti]], losing to [[Helen Stevenson Meyner]].{{harvnb|Wright Jr.|1977}}.{{cite web| last=Rudin| first=Ken| title=The Watergate Class Of 1974: How They Arrived In Congress, How They Left| date=June 19, 2012| url=https://www.npr.org/sections/politicaljunkie/2012/06/19/155063336/the-watergate-class-of-1974-how-they-arrived-in-congress-how-they-left| publisher=NPR| accessdate=November 17, 2019}} Regarding the Judiciary Committee's process and its momentous recommendation that President Nixon be impeached and removed from office, Rodino, in a 1989 interview with [[Susan Stamberg]] of [[National Public Radio]], said: {{quote|Notwithstanding the fact that I was a Democrat, notwithstanding the fact that there were many who thought that Rodino wanted to bring down a president as a Democrat, you know, he was our president. And this is our system that was being tested. And here was a man who had achieved the highest office that anyone could gift him with, you know. And you're bringing down the presidency of the United States, and it was a sad, sad commentary on our whole history and, of course, on Richard Nixon.}} == See also == * [[Impeachment of Andrew Johnson]] * [[Impeachment of Bill Clinton]] * [[Impeachment of Donald Trump]] * [[List of federal political scandals in the United States]] == Notes == {{notelist|30em}} == References == {{reflist}} == Works cited == === Books and journals === {{ref begin|2}} * {{cite book| title=Little Giant: The Life and Times of Speaker Carl Albert| url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Little_Giant.html?id=rNtc9D6AJ8wC| last=Albert| first=Carl| authorlink=Carl Albert| others=With Danney Goble| publisher=University of Oklahoma Press| location=Norman, Oklahoma| year=1990| isbn=0-8061-2250-1| ref=harv}} * {{cite book| last=Ambrose| first=Stephen E.| authorlink=Stephen E.
